p: Dengue fever was listed as a major threat to global health in 2019 by the World Health Organization, aiming to reduce half of the deaths resulting from dengue infection by 2020 (WHO, https://www.who.int/emergencies/ten-threats-to-global-health-in-2019). Dengue infection is a mosquito-borne disease widely distributed in tropical and subtropical countries with its clinical symptoms ranging from mild dengue fever to severe dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) or dengue shock syndrome (DSS)[ 1]. Approximately two-fifths of the world population are under threat of dengue infection with nearly 390 million infections annually, and it is mainly distributed in Southeast Asia, Africa, Eastern Mediterranean, Americas, and Western Pacific [ 2].
